results.content:
The instructor is skilled and has experience. Furthermore, he is an enthusiast, sometimes when you struggle with the code you need a positive attitude. 
The course delivers what it promises: in the end, you learn to write a modern (Mysqli) and effective login/registration system with password_hash ( check the extras) "and" with the usual md5 encrypting. The exposition style is fast and straight to the point, he comments and explains quickly what a string is going to do before or after writing it. The downloadable files are useful when you struggle to find where you misplaced a dot or a single comma.

As I like his style, I will sure follow other courses from him when needed. Recommended.

results.content:
The lecture is bad - because it promotes bad practices.

Don't get me wrong, I'm not saying the lecturer is bad, or I am good, I'm just saying he has gotten a few "facts" or "practices" wrong.

Background about myself: 
I don't do PHP, and you shouldn't either. PHP is downright a badly designed language. Why did I take this course then? My current job required me to write in PHP, and since I really avoid PHP (because it's so bad), I was hoping someone would give a safe and secure way to write an account system - turns out, I was wrong - its neither secure nor safe. 

For more information why PHP is such a bad language, please refer to : https://eev.ee/blog/2012/04/09/php-a-fractal-of-bad-design/

Pros of the lecture:
- I like the lectuerer's style
- Resources are well prepared
- Lecturer is engaging, lively, makes you not sleep!
- Lecturer is very excited, people that are excited gets you excited!
- Looks to me like he response really fast
- Lecturer promotes self-coding instead of copy paste! This is an example of a good teacher
- Instructive.
- Excellent Accent <3

Cons of the lecture:
- Lecturer lack some basic knowledge on security :
   > password is never encrpyted - encryption is very different from hashing - the concept is very very very different, terms should NOT be used interchangably
  > md5 is insecure, it will take a $3/month cloud server to break the database in a week or so.
  > escape_real_blahblah is a BAD practice. Never escape SQL or database queries. Sanitizing inputs should never be promoted. Escaping strings is a security loophole. Why? There is no such thing as SQL injection but improperly formatted query.
 > using cookies for as a "login verification" is like, the most unsecure design in this whole course. If the user as email cookie containing user's email, then he is considered logged in? That means if I simply write a cookie textfile and add to it my broswer with YOUR email, I'm considered logged in to your account simply by knowing your email. If you want to use cookies, the bare minimum is to store and IP in the database and a time-based verification token (hashed with anything but md5), as a cookie, and verify it with the database, even then its not very safe.

-  Not much of "lectures" as watching him write code, with bad syntax error every other minute. I mean sure we all write syntax errors, but its kinda excessive in this one.
- Correcting syntax error is NOT debugging, and debugging is NOT fun, especially in PHP
- Lack of explanation of workflow, structure and macroskills. Too much explanation of microskills. Not what a lecture should be like.
- Not that it matters, but it should "Stay logged in" then "Remember me" button, really. 
- Too much newlines between codes - not sure why. Better to be able to see more code on a screen.
- Code indentation is really bad - its good practice to use proper indention: makes your code more readable, leading to less syntax errors, and in many other languages, indentation matters.
- Its PHP. Period.

This is not a beginner level course.  You will need a solid understanding of php, html, and mysql to be able to keep up.  You will also need to have a working web server with php installed and a working mysql database server on your local system.  The instructor does not go through the process of getting these components up and running, but they are required.

results.content:
Loved this course. Thanks so much for teaching it Edwin. 

I do have a couple of things I would love to see if possible. 
1.) I would love it if you added to the course some code that did validation for changing passwords. How do I force the user to choose a password that they haven't used already the last couple of times before? How do I force the user to choose passwords that have at least one capital letter, a number and or a special character in them? Probably need a regex here.
2.) Is it safe to auto populate the code.php code validation field? I have done so with the $_GET['code'] command successfully. I would think that would be alright as it is already in the url. I am just thinking that it would help the user as they wouldn't even need to enter it as long as they clicked on the link provided to them in their email. Here is what I did successfully with that on the code.php page: <input type="text" name="code" id="code" tabindex="1" class="form-control" placeholder="##########" value="<?php if(isset($_GET['code'])) echo $_GET['code']; ?>" autocomplete="off" required/>  Adding something like this to your course might be nice. I'm just thinking the end user wouldn't want to have to type in that long number especially because  some end users have trouble with even copy and paste. I know that sounds crazy but I have seen it where I work. Some people are computer challenged. The easier it is for them the better. 

Thanks again for the wonderful course. I loved it. I learned a lot from it.

results.content:
Preface: I'm intermediate with PHP. I'd say a 4 out of 10 in ability and experience. 

This is hands down the best course I've seen when it comes to PHP registration/login/etc. I had signed up for a different course (which I won't name) and about 10 minutes into it I realized it was lacking a massive amount of information. I got a refund and signed up for Edwin's course. Best decision.

Why is this course good? Let me tell you.

1. It is very comprehensive. The subject matter can be nuanced and many other free and paid instructions miss a lot of important points. Edwin's (while still having a couple of blind spots) is hands down the most exhaustive I've seen. Simple things, like email confirmation.

2. His script actually works and can be incorporated easily into any project. I only had to do a little massaging, which is a compliment. 

***Still I recommend actually watching the course, don't just copypasta the script***

3. Which brings me to point #3...Edwin covers PHP topics that he could have easily skipped over, but thankfully didn't. A good example is configuration and helper functions. This is important to understand - not just for this course but in general- and I'm a better programmer for having watched his instruction in these areas. 

I will be taking many more of his courses.

Once again, great course and I can't wait to begin my next course by Edwin!

results.content: When you will follow Edwins steps, in "user registration" when user submits invalid values (too short username etc) don't forget to return them back to the form so user can easily correct them (not write new from the scratch). Anyway.. this course is good starting point.

results.content: Too much coding on the fly, too many errors and too much time spent on debugging silly errors that should not be in a professional course.  Whilst the course is very instructive, it is difficult to watch errors being made on the fly and then 5 minutes watching debugging when the video should have been planned properly in the first place.
results.content_html: Too much coding on the fly, too many errors and too much time spent on debugging silly errors that should not be in a professional course.
